page.title: 07RIVER ESK THROUGH RAVENGLASS
page.content: The river Esk rises from the "Knotts of Tongue",2400 feet above sea level, and is fed by many tributary streams on its 20 mile journey to the sea at Ravenglass,where it joins the rivers Irt and Mite in a unique multiple estuary.The largest of the tributary streams are the Whillan Beck,which takes the outflow from Burnmoor Tarn, and Lincove Beck,which drains Long Top and Birker Fell. The Esk is a typical spate river,and the level can rise by several feet an hour when heavy rains on the fells produce flood conditions. The river was once famous for its runs of sea trout (and to a lesser extent salmon),but catches have been poor in recent years and at present there is a voluntary embargo on fishing.The cause of the decrease in the migratory fish population is under investigation by the North West Water Authority.
